unnormalised: So, you bravely ventured into the marketplace, Rs. 2000 lighter, clutching that shiny new pressure cooker from "Bharat Appliances," convinced you'd finally conquer the Everest of chhole bhature. But alas, disaster strikes! The whistling sound rivals a Kalyan station announcement at peak hour, and your chhole bhature dreams are bubbling over... literally. Time for a return!

unnormalised: But hold your horses, or rather, your jalebi! Navigating return policies these days is like trying to find a parking spot in Chandni Chowk on Diwali – a chaotic, often frustrating, adventure.

unnormalised: Every store, both online and that dusty old corner shop run by Sharma Ji, seems to have its own unique brand of rules. Some offer a blissful 30-day, no-questions-asked return window (bless their souls!). Others, well, let's just say they require a blood sample, a detailed report from Dr. Gupta, and a signed affidavit from your nani before even considering it.

unnormalised: Then there's the fine print, thicker than a Chetan Bhagat novel. Did you accidentally remove the barcode while trying to open the packaging with your teeth? Sorry beta, no return. Did you use the item, even just once, and now it's “damaged”? Good luck explaining that to their return department. They’ll probably accuse you of using it as a cricket bat in your 1000 sq ft apartment in Mumbai.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on online shopping! You order that gorgeous silk saree from "Saree Sensations," expecting Deepika Padukone elegance. What arrives looks more like a dishrag someone found near the banks of the Ganges. But the return process? Prepare for an email chain that rivals the length of the Ramayana and a courier pick-up service that may or may not actually show up.
